title: Dollar Demand Vanishes On Ugly Data
text:
Kathy Lien, Managing Director Of FX Strategy For BK Asset Management

Daily FX Market Roundup October 1, 2019

With the exception of and , all of the major currencies traded lower Tuesday against the greenback with the lead the slide. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut for the third time this year to a record low of 0.75% but the big story is the near-term top in . The US dollar started the NY session firm against all major currencies and at multi-year highs versus the euro but it u-turned after ISM. According to the latest report, factory activity hit its weakest level in 10 years. contracted for the second month in row with the index slipping to 47.8 from 49.1. This deterioration raises concerns about how weaker global growth is affecting the US economy and by extension the labor market. Although is a separate line item in Friday’s , the fact that the dropped to its lowest level since 2016 is a red flag for the economy and jobs. We’ll know more when the is released on Thursday but for now, today’s report changed the course for the by setting expectations for a soft release. Aside from the pullback in the dollar, Treasury yields turned negative and the tumbled more than 300 points. If Wednesday’s misses expectations, we could see a more significant sell-off that could drive below 107.50.

Thanks to the decline in the , we may also see a near-term bottom in . The outlook for the Eurozone is grim and the European Union’s denial of reports they are considering a time limited back stop doesn’t help any of the European currencies. However the risk of a short covering is high ahead of Friday’s report and investors could use the excuse that manufacturing PMI numbers were revised upwards for the month of September. The manufacturing sector is still very weak but a short squeeze could take EUR/USD to 1.10 without breaking the downtrend.

The was the worst-performing currency, which is no surprise given the Reserve Bank’s decision to lower for the third time this year. They took rates to a record low and said they are “prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed.” They expect inflationary pressures to remain subdued for some time and expressed concerns about the outlook for consumption. Indicators suggest that employment growth will slow because as per Governor Lowe, the “progress on jobs and inflation is slower than we’d like.” While we don’t think the RBA will ease again this year, today’s was more dovish than the market anticipated. dropped to a 4-year low because the rate cut by the RBA puts pressure on the RBNZ to ease.

sold off despite softer-than-expected growth and lower . The move was driven entirely by weakness. Although the decline stopped short of breaking the 2-week-long range, the fact that USD/CAD ended the NY session at its weekly low makes the downside vulnerable to a break. If USD/CAD drops below 1.32, we could see a swift slide to 1.3150. Last but not least, ended the day unchanged against the US dollar. Stronger-than-expected helped to prevent fresh losses but the main focus is Brexit. If the EU offers concessions on the Irish backstop, GBP/USD will rip higher but until that happens, big moves in sterling could be limited.
